questions.question: Which of the following can be determined using the cephalic index?
questions.explanation: The cephalic index is a numerical value used in physical anthropology to specify the shape of the head, and it can be used to determine race.

questions.question: Which of the following best describes a skull belonging to an Indian man?
questions.explanation: The skull of Indians can be classified as mesocephalic. This type of skull is of intermediate length and width. The skull of an Indian is Caucasian with a few Negroid characteristics. Because of racial mixing, the Indian skull cannot be correctly differentiated into the broad categories of dolichocephalic, mesocephalic, and brachycephalic. Note: This is a controversial question. The use of the cephalic index for the determination of race has been discredited and the cephalic index of the entire Indian population cannot be generalized to belong to one category. But the best answer to this question is mesocephalic. Type of skull: Cephalic index: Race. Dolichocephalic: 70-74.9: Europeans, Aborigines, Negros. Mesocephalic: 75-79.9: Pure Aryans, Aborigines, Europeans, Chinese, Indians. Brachycephalic: 80-84.9: Mongolians.

questions.question: The forensic department has received the post-mortem remains of a partly decayed body recovered from the outskirts near an international airport. They notice that an oval cross-section of hair is seen on the scalp. What would have been the likely race of the person?
questions.explanation: Round or ovoid cross-section of hair is found in the Caucasian race. Race determination from hair: Hair cross-section - Elliptical: Race - Negroid, Round to Ovoid: Caucasoids, Circular/Cylindrical: Mongoloids

questions.question: Human skeletal remains were found in an abandoned basement in Wuhan. Which of the following would indicate that the victim was a Caucasian?

options.D: Lack of the third upper molar

questions.explanation: Carabelli's cusps are most commonly seen only in Caucasian races and are rare in the other major racial groups. These are small nodules on the lingual surface of maxillary molars. Features of Mongoloid dentition include: shovel-shaped upper central incisors - posterior surfaces of these teeth have a central depression; enamel pearls - small nodules of enamel on the tooth surface; Taurodontism (bull-tooth) - pulp cavity of molars is wide and deep; a congenital lack of the third upper molar.

questions.question: Which of the following is false regarding teeth features and ethnicity?

options.A: In Africanoids, the cusps of molars are wide and deep, and shovel-shaped cusps are found in incisors
options.C: The upper third molar is most commonly absent in Mongolians
options.D: Prominent lingual ridge and labial ridge in Mongols

questions.explanation: The cusps of molars are wide and deep, and the cusps of incisors are shovel-shaped in Mongoloid races. Africanoid races tend to have large teeth and often have more cusps on their molars, even up to eight, with two lingual cusps on the mandibular first premolars as an additional common finding. In Caucasian races, the lateral incisors in the upper jaw are usually smaller than the central. They also have long, pointed canine roots. Small nodules on the lingual surface of maxillary molars, called Carabelli's cusp, are most common in Caucasian races. In Mongoloid teeth, enamel pearls and small nodules of enamel on the tooth surface are much more frequent. The condition of bull-tooth or taurodontism is most common in Mongoloid people. The pulp cavity of molars is wide and deep, and the roots are fused and bent. A congenital lack of the third upper molar is most commonly seen. The lingual and labial ridges are more prominent.

questions.question: What is the identification of the preauricular sulcus useful for?
questions.explanation: The preauricular sulcus is useful for sex determination. It is a groove on the iliac bone, broad and deep in a female pelvis and narrow and shallow in a male pelvis. The differences between male and female pelvis are summarized in the table below. Characteristic: General Morphology, Overall shape, Preauricular sulcus, Acetabulum, Body of pubis, Obturator foramen, Subpubic angle, Greater sciatic notch, Ischial Tuberosity, Pelvic Brim. Male pelvis: Massive, rougher, marked muscle attachments, Deep funnel, Narrow, shallow, Large, wider, deeper, Narrow, triangular, thick, Large, oval with base upward, V-shaped, narrow, (700), Smaller, narrower, deeper, Inverted, Heart-Shaped. Female pelvis: Less massive, slender, smoother, Flat bowl, Broad, deep, Small, narrower, Broad, square, Small, triangular with apex forwards, U-shaped, rounded, wide, (900), Larger, wider, shallower, Everted, more widely separated, Circular or elliptical, Larger. Pelvic outlet: Smaller, Sacroiliac articulation: Large extends to 2 1/2 to 3 vertebrae, Small, oblique, extends to 2 to 2 1/2 vertebrae, Sacroiliac joint surface: Large and less sharply angular, L-shaped and elevated anterolaterally. Characteristic: Sacrum, Male pelvis: Longer, narrower, with more evenly distributed curvature, promontory well marked. Body of first sacral vertebra is larger. Female pelvis: Shorter, wider; upper half almost straight, curve forward in the lower half, promontory less marked. Body of first sacral vertebra is small.

questions.question: Which of the following statements about sex chromatin is false?

options.A: Two Barr bodies are seen in a person with 47,XXY genetic makeup
options.B: Barr body may be seen in a genetic male
options.C: Davidson body seen in neutrophil nucleus
options.D: A common site for sex chromatin sampling is tooth pulp

questions.explanation: The number of Barr bodies in someone with 47,XXY genetic makeup is 1, not 2. The number of Barr bodies is given by the formula n-1, where n is the number of X chromosomes. Barr body is a small planoconvex mass, lying near the nuclear membrane. It represents the inactivated X chromosome. Barr bodies are seen in 0-4% of genetic males (46,XY) and 20-80% of genetic females (46,XX). Sites for sampling for sex chromatin include buccal mucosa, tooth pulp, and hair bulb. Davidson body is a drumstick-shaped mass of chromatin hanging down from neutrophil nuclei. It is seen only in females (0-6%).

questions.question: Which of the following indices are used to determine the sex of an individual?
questions.explanation: Sternal index, corporobasal sacral index, and ischiopubic index are used to determine the sex of the individual. The intermembral index and cephalic index are helpful in determining the race of the individual. Indices for sex determination: Indices Calculation (x100) Male Female Ischiopubic index Length of pubis/Length of ischium <90 >95 Corporobasal index Transverse diameter of body of S1/Breadth of base of sacrum 40-53 35-45 Sciatic notch index Maximum breadth of greater sciatic notch / Maximum depth of greater sciatic notch Transverse diameter of base of sacrum / Length of sacrum 34-45 55-60 <114 >114 Indices Calculation (x100) Male Female Sternal index Length of manubrium / Length of mesosternum 32-38 44-50

questions.question: You are asked to determine the sex of a person from the skeletal remains found on an empty site. Which of the following bones is most accurate for the same?
questions.explanation: The whole pelvis is the most reliable bone for sex determination. Krogman's degree of accuracy in sex determination from adult skeletal remains: • Entire skeleton - 100% • Pelvis plus skull - 98% • Long bones and pelvis > 95% • Pelvis alone - 95% • Long bones and skull - 90-95% • Skull alone - 90% • Long bones alone - 80-90%

questions.question: What is the minimum age beyond which sex determination based on a skeleton would be highly accurate?
questions.explanation: Minimum age of a skeleton beyond which sex determination would be highly accurate is 14-16 years. This is because most marked changes regarding sex differences occur in the skeleton post-puberty. In prepubertal skeletons, the chance of a correct sex allocation is only 50%. If the pelvis is present, the chances of correct sex allocation increase to about 80%.

questions.question: How would the structures marked as 1 and 2 be described in a female skull?
questions.explanation: The structures marked as 1 and 2 are the frontal and parietal eminences. In a female skull, the frontal eminence is large, but the parietal eminence is small. Differentiating features between male and female skull: The features given above develop after puberty and are modified by senility. Hence, the differences are applicable only between 18-55 years. The image given below shows a male and female skull. The red arrow indicates frontal bossing, which is more apparent in the male skull. The green arrow indicates nasal radix, which is deeper in the male skull. The yellow arrow indicates greater prominence of the chin in the male skull. The blue arrow shows a greater mandibular height in the male skull. Trait: Male - General size: Large, Architecture: Rugged, Supraorbital ridge: Prominent, Mastoid process: Prominent. Female - General size: Small, Architecture: Smooth, Supraorbital ridge: Less prominent, Mastoid process: Less prominent. Occipital region: Marked muscle markings in male, no marked muscle markings in female. Frontal eminences: Small in male, large in female. Parietal eminence: Small in female. Orbits: Large in male, small in female. Mandible: Large, broad ramus in male, small, small ramus in female. Chin shape: Square with round margins in male, round with sharp margins in female.

questions.question: What is the Bertillon system used for?
questions.explanation: The Bertillon system is used for identification based on anthropometry. The origins of forensic anthropology can be traced to the end of the nineteenth century when the French criminologist Alphonse Bertillon devised the first classification and identification system to identify criminals, based on anthropometry.

questions.question: You have measured the femur length to be 40 cm from the skeletal remains of an unknown person. What is the approximate height of the individual?
questions.explanation: The approximate height of the individual is 150 cm. The stature/femur relationship is 3.74. Thus, stature can be calculated by using the formula: stature = femur length x 3.74 = 40 x 3.74 = 149.6 cm = 150 cm. The relationship between the mean stature and the mean length of the femur appears to be fairly stable around the world. However, this factor tends to overestimate tall and underestimate short individuals.

questions.question: Which of the following can be estimated using Pearson's formula?
questions.explanation: Pearson's formula is used for the estimation of stature. Methods of determination of stature: 1. Pearson's formula: Any bone may be used, but the measurement of one or more of the six long bones provides the most reliable estimates. The descending order of usefulness of bones is femur > tibia > humerus > radius. 2. Trotter and Gleser's method - Formula for stature (cm) = 1.30 (Femur + Tibia) + 63.29 (+/-2.99). 3. Stature/femur relationship - The relationship between the mean stature and the mean length of the femur appears to be fairly stable around the world, which is 3.74. 4. Anatomical method - This is the most accurate method. It consists of the sum of the following parameters: • Basibregmatic height of the skull ⚫ Height of the vertebrae from the axis through the first sacral vertebra • Bicondylar length of the femur • Physiological length of the tibia • Articulated height of the talus and calcaneus • A constant is added to account for the soft tissues. Note: Pearson also introduced the principle of regression.

questions.question: Crown Rump Length is 21 cm, length of lower limb is 10 cm, gestational age of the fetus will be:
questions.explanation: Gestational age of this fetus is 6-7 months. Crown rump length + length of lower limb = crown heel length. Rule of Haase enables the estimation of the age of the fetus in lunar months from its crown-heel length (in cm). According to the rule, • Age in months = Square root of crown-heel length (when the crown-heel length is 25 cm or less/first 5 months). Age in months = crown-heel length divided by 5 (when the crown-heel length is more than 25 cm/last 5 months). Here, crown heel length = Crown rump + lower limb length = 31 cm. Hence, gestational age = 31 / 5 = 6-7 months.

questions.question: What percent of the stature of an individual is contributed by the length of the vertebral column?
questions.explanation: The length of the vertebral column is 35 percent of the stature of an individual. Bone percent of height: Humerus 20, Tibia 22-40, Bone percent of height: Femur 27, Spine 35

questions.question: A forensic expert is examining the pelvic bone and lower vertebrae of an unknown individual, to determine the sex. Which of the following is regarded as the best source of information for the same?
questions.explanation: The greater sciatic notch, which is a part of the ilium, is the ideal feature to determine sex. The sacrum is the least reliable bone for sex determination. The femur is the most useful long bone for sex determination, due to its length and massiveness. Pearson and Bell's criteria for sexing of the femur are: • Vertical diameter of the femoral head - most useful criterion • Popliteal length • Bicondylar width • Oblique trochanteric length
